headline.main: For Conservatives on Health Law, It's 'Repeal or Nothing'

docs.abstract: As Republicans observe the second anniversary of the signing of President Obama's health care law this week, a new motto is emerging that could hurt the law's implementation: Repeal or nothing.
docs.snippet: As Republicans observe the second anniversary of the signing of President Obama's health care law this week, a new motto is emerging that could hurt the law's implementation: Repeal or nothing.

headline.main: Health Care Debate Returns With Intensity
headline.print_headline: Debate on Health Care Returns With Intensity

docs.abstract: The health care reform law's two-year anniversary and Supreme Court arguments on its constitutionality will push the subject to the front of political agenda in the coming weeks.
docs.snippet: The health care reform law's two-year anniversary and Supreme Court arguments on its constitutionality will push the subject to the front of political agenda in the coming weeks.

docs.lead_paragraph: Research shows that most women still pay more for health insurance than men, though the 2010 health care reform law will prohibit such “gender rating” beginning in two years.

headline.seo: Women Still Pay More for Health Insurance, Data Shows
headline.main: Gender Gap Persists in Cost of Health Insurance
headline.print_headline: Gender Gap Persists as Health Insurers Resist Adopting Law Early

docs.abstract: Research by the National Women's Law Center finds that 90 percent of women still pay more than men for the same health insurance coverage in states that do not prohibit gender discrimination by insurers; women's health advocates recommend that insurers begin voluntarily narrowing the gap in order to reduce the impact that will occur in 2014, when new federal health care laws will force them to raise rates for men in order to achieve parity.
docs.snippet: Research shows that most women still pay more for health insurance than men, though the 2010 health care reform law will prohibit such “gender rating” beginning in two years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite some imperfections, the Affordable Care Act would do a lot of good and must be defended.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column mounts a defense of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act; contends that one indicator of how good the law is comes from the apparent inability of its opponents to make an honest case against it.
docs.snippet: Despite some imperfections, the Affordable Care Act would do a lot of good and must be defended.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: For months, Mitt Romney has tried to deflect attention from his rivals' accusations that his health care plan was the inspiration for President Obama's overhaul. That task will be harder in the coming days. This week is the two-year anniversary of Mr. Obama's health care law, and Republicans in Washington are planning to celebrate with a series of attacks. Next week, the Supreme Court will hear three days of arguments about whether the law is constitutional. The hoopla will be enormous.

headline.main: Debate on Health Care Returns With Intensity

docs.abstract: Caucus column; Republicans are planning a broad media assault on the Affordable Care Act at the national, state and local levels, occasioned by the law's two-year anniversary and its upcoming review by the Supreme Court; assault will grant Mitt Romney's presidential opponents a fresh opportunity to draw comparisons to the health care laws he introduced as governor of Massachusetts. (M)
